DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: That's pretty ingenious. I bet you can work around the clock.
RESPONSE TEXT: Of course, darling. Our unique hierarchy allows for constant operation.
DIALOGUE AFTER: SupervisorWhite: You see, there are two kinds of robots here.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Robots can do simple tasks, sure, but you need a human being to make the big decisions.
RESPONSE TEXT: Ah, but that's where Graygarden is unique, darling.
We're not just simple robots. We have a unique social structure - a hierachy, if you will.
DIALOGUE AFTER: SupervisorWhite: You see, there are two kinds of robots here.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: This place seems familiar. I think I saw a bit about it on the news, back before the war.
RESPONSE TEXT: Yes, construction was completed mere days before the war.
We were able to survive and continue our operations only because our creator made us fully self-sufficient.
DIALOGUE AFTER: SupervisorWhite: You see, there are two kinds of robots here.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: There's not even one person here?
RESPONSE TEXT: That's right, darling. We are entirely self-sufficient, with no need for human guidance.
DIALOGUE AFTER: SupervisorWhite: You see, there are two kinds of robots here.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: SupervisorWhite: Of course, darling. Our unique hierarchy allows for constant operation.
RESPONSE TEXT: You see, there are two kinds of robots here.
The worker drones carry out labor and maintenance.
We supervisors - that is, myself, Greene and Brown - possess sophisticated cognition processors.
We are capable of complex analysis and decision-making, a testament to the genius of our creator, Doctor Edward Gray.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Obviously, the man was brilliant to come up with something like this.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Obviously, the man was brilliant to come up with something like this.
RESPONSE TEXT: I could hardly have said it better myself, darling.
DIALOGUE AFTER: SupervisorWhite: Robotics and artificial intelligence were our creator's great passions, rivaled only by his love of television.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Only a madman would think that artificial intelligence could replace human intuition and experience.
RESPONSE TEXT: You misunderstand him, darling. He wanted only to know what a machine was truly capable of.
DIALOGUE AFTER: SupervisorWhite: Robotics and artificial intelligence were our creator's great passions, rivaled only by his love of television.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I remember him. He was one of RobCo's senior engineers, but more than a little eccentric.
RESPONSE TEXT: That's the second time you've said that you remember something before the war.
I think you're a little confused darling. You simply can't have been alive back then.
DIALOGUE AFTER: SupervisorWhite: Robotics and artificial intelligence were our creator's great passions, rivaled only by his love of television.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I remember him. He was one of RobCo's senior engineers, but more than a little eccentric.
RESPONSE TEXT: You seem a bit confused, darling.
You're far too young to remember anything that happened before the war.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I was in a vault. They put me in cryogenic freeze.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: What became of Doctor Gray?
RESPONSE TEXT: Like so many others, he died in the war. It was a terrible loss.
DIALOGUE AFTER: SupervisorWhite: Robotics and artificial intelligence were our creator's great passions, rivaled only by his love of television.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I could hardly have said it better myself, darling.
RESPONSE TEXT: Robotics and artificial intelligence were our creator's great passions, rivaled only by his love of television.
Perhaps you've noticed that I possess a rather singular personality, as do the other supervisors.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Companion: That's puttin' it mildly.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Well, it's definitely unique. Sort of hard to miss.
RESPONSE TEXT: I'll take that as a compliment, darling.
After all, the last thing any woman wants to be is ordinary.
DIALOGUE AFTER: SupervisorWhite: A few other things you should know... talk to Greene if you need supplies.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: A tin can that talks like a femme fatale is still a tin can.
RESPONSE TEXT: Some men know how to talk to a woman. The rest are more like you.
DIALOGUE AFTER: SupervisorWhite: A few other things you should know... talk to Greene if you need supplies.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Why did Doctor Gray give you these unusual personalities?
RESPONSE TEXT: Genius is restless, darling. It abhors stagnation. Doctor Gray was tired of the standard Mister Handy personality.
He looked to his favorite television characters for inspiration, and we are the result.
DIALOGUE AFTER: SupervisorWhite: A few other things you should know... talk to Greene if you need supplies.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I was in a vault. They put me in cryogenic freeze.
RESPONSE TEXT: Remarkable! I must say, darling, you seem very well-preserved.
DIALOGUE AFTER: SupervisorWhite: Now, where was I...

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Just forget I said it.
RESPONSE TEXT: Of course, darling. I can see it's a sensitive subject for you.
DIALOGUE AFTER: SupervisorWhite: Now, where was I...

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: It's a long story.
RESPONSE TEXT: Of course, darling. A lady knows when not to pry.
DIALOGUE AFTER: SupervisorWhite: Now, where was I...

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You haven't met anyone else who was around back then?
RESPONSE TEXT: I'm sorry to disappoint you, darling, but no.
In my experience, you are unique.
DIALOGUE AFTER: SupervisorWhite: Now, where was I...

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Remarkable! I must say, darling, you seem very well-preserved.
RESPONSE TEXT: Now, where was I...
Ah yes, Edward Gray.
DIALOGUE AFTER: SupervisorWhite: Robotics and artificial intelligence were our creator's great passions, rivaled only by his love of television.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: After all, the last thing any woman wants to be is ordinary.
RESPONSE TEXT: A few other things you should know... talk to Greene if you need supplies.
If it's caps you need, Brown might have a few odd jobs.
DIALOGUE AFTER: SupervisorWhite: Farewell for now, dahling.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: SupervisorWhite: Farewell for now, dahling.
RESPONSE TEXT: Ah, there's one other thing. A question, really.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: SupervisorWhite: If it's caps you need, Brown might have a few odd jobs.
RESPONSE TEXT: Farewell for now, dahling.
DIALOGUE AFTER: SupervisorWhite: Ah, there's one other thing. A question, really.

RESPONSE TEXT: You've gone too far, dahling!
SCRIPT NOTES: (See notes for Supervisor White) Shouting, starting a fight.

RESPONSE TEXT: I can't allow that!
SCRIPT NOTES: (See notes for Supervisor White) Shouting, starting a fight.

RESPONSE TEXT: How dare you!
SCRIPT NOTES: (See notes for Supervisor White) Shouting, starting a fight.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Brown: Well, it just seems to be a tad slow of late, as if it's not running on a full charge.
RESPONSE TEXT: It's probably just a defect in the power unit. I'll have a look at it later.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Brown: Jolly good. Just let me know if we need a new power unit and I'll see if can't make a trade for one.

RESPONSE TEXT: The mutfruit's looking ripe, darling. You should gather some up for Brown to sell.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Greene: Whoa, there! Just hold your horses, little lady.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Greene: It's going to be a few more weeks before this fruit produces that sweet, delicious taste your kids will love.
RESPONSE TEXT: Well I simply can't agree, darling. Call it a woman's intuition if you like, but this crop is ready now.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Greene: Oh, I'm so sorry but that is the wrong answer.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Greene: Better luck next time, but hey, thanks for playing!
RESPONSE TEXT: Have it your way, but don't say I didn't warn you, darling.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Greene: Supervisor White, you're the next contestant!
RESPONSE TEXT: What do you want, darling? And please make it quick, I haven't got all day.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Greene: Bad news, I'm afraid.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Greene: Our latest mutfruit crop is coming in smaller than usual, and some of the fruit isn't ripening quickly enough.
RESPONSE TEXT: Again? It's got to be the water. It's been getting more toxic by the day, and now it's affecting the plants.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Greene: Well, if something isn't done soon, it'll be game over for the entire crop.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Greene: Without fruit to sell to the traders, we won't have caps to buy the spare parts we need to keep running.
RESPONSE TEXT: Then let's hope we can find someone willing to help us, darling.
